After "The Lost World Jurassic Park" everyone believed that the franchise was dead but four years later, another sequel to the beloved 1993 film arrived but without Spielberg in the directing chair and not based on a novel. 
Dr Alan Grant is convinced to go to Isla Sorna as a tour guide by the wealthy Kirby marriage but soon after they arrive to the island, mayhem breaks lose again with Dr Grant being the only capable person to assure the survival of the group. 
After the questionable ending of "Lost World", it seemed to be no reason to make a third film but Universal Studios decided to make a film that no one wanted to see. "Jurassic Park 3" never attempts to recapture the magic of the first film, it knows it is a cash grab sequel. This third instalment goes to typical sequel territory: It tries to recreate some settings/shots of the first film, it goes for the "bigger baddy" cliché, it brings some familiar faces back, B movie level of acting, laughable scenes (not only the infamous dream sequence), the new characters are more than forgettable and have no personality whatsoever, the special effects look extremely dated- ironic don't you think?- , Joe Johnson´s directing is as generic as always, the most ridiculous script of the entire series, the story is pretty cliché and generic, the pacing is so fast that you will stop to remember how you ended up in a scene, and this feels like the PG version of "Jurassic Park" due to the lack of intense/violent sequences. To be honest, there are only three elements that elevate this film a little: Sam Neil, the Pteranodons sequence, as they were the only dinosaur that Spielberg never gave their deserved moment; and that before you know it the film is over.
"Jurassic Park 3" feels like a parody of the original. As a B movie it is serviceable but as an addition to the franchise, it is unnecessary, forgettable and laughable. There goes Spielberg, there goes this franchise´s magic (will see if "Jurassic World" proves me wrong but I really doubt it)

The weakest of the three. Something about JPIII just rang hollow throughout. Visually, you will most certainly notice that while the special FX are far more advanced than the first movie, you'll also probably feel as I did: that it wasn't impressive and it was over-used. The film relies too heavily on special FX and it drowns out the realism from the first two. This may also have to do with the fact that the film takes place a lot of the time during the day, whereas the previous installments used a lot of night sequences. Sure, there were some pretty moments, such as the scene by the river. Nevertheless, with all these effects, you start to feel like you're watching a movie from the SyFy channel and that wasn't a good thing at all. I guess this marks the beginning of the era when filmmakers decided to get lazy and turn movies mostly into special effects extravaganzas. 

Additionally, I took up issue with the dinosaurs. Yeah, they looked cooler with their hip new color patterns instead of the simple mud-brown palette they were almost unilaterally assigned in the first two. My big issue is with the velociraptors.

We've known from the very first movie that raptors are extremely intelligent, agile, and astute problem solvers which, coupled with their basic predatory instinct, easily made them the scariest foes for the humans to face. I guess without the presence of humans on this particular site for all these years, we are supposed to get the idea that the raptors have become doubly intelligent. So instead of believable animals with intelligent hunting strategies, we get creatures that feel more like reptilian mobsters. They expertly break necks and camouflage themselves as science experiments in labs (i.e., the raptor holding perfectly still behind the glass before leaping out at them.) They are so smart that the humans running from them start to look like idiots as they scream and holler for each other in the middle of the jungle, presence of man-eating dinosaurs be damned. At least with the first one you got the idea that they were really intelligent problem-solvers but they were still animals. I'm surprised they didn't bust out in mocking laughter when Grant pulled out that instrument  that could mimic their calls. You can tell this was directed by someone else. 

And while I like Dr. Grant, he's honestly kind of boring on his own. Especially since the other characters on-screen aren't very interesting themselves. The last time we saw him he was with kids and his character kind of grew from that experience and spending time with them. Here, he leaves the movie the same way he was when we first saw him. The "evolving" is left to the Kirby family. 

In short, if you really want to enjoy this movie do your best not to think about the first two. I hope the next one is better.

Jurassic Park III truly delivered a new dinosaur that was desperately needed in the franchise. While T-Rex and Velociraptor are the stars of the series, adding Spinosaurus into the mix truly upped the danger for the cast stranded on Isla Sorna. The cast was both dynamic, but the story was simple and it made for an even better movie that the second, Jurassic Park The Lost World.

While I can't say that this film holds a candle to the first film on a storytelling level, it's at least here to do what it's supposed to do: be a fun film. And it gets to the point pretty fast and does so in a far more effective way than The Lost World: Jurassic Park. While that film was over two hours of whining environmentalists given far too much time to shoot their mouths off, this film at least understands that it's characters are not its strong point. And therefore, it doesn't waste too much time on them.

But with that... yeah... the characters are pretty lame. There's Tea Leoni and her scream that gets pretty old pretty fast. There's Sam Neil reprising his role as the reluctant Alan Grant, who seems far too easily swayed to return to the island for cash after his spiteful statements against it in the beginning. And there's Billy, played by Alessandro Nivola. And his character seems really bland and underdeveloped.

The story has a million holes in it, too. For example: why would any parents let their twelve year old child go on a trip anywhere near an island filled with dangerous dinosaurs? Why would there still be any need for paleontological digs if we could just create dinosaurs anytime? Doesn't that seem like wasted funding? Why can the biggest baddest predator of all time (Spinosaurus) kill a t-rex in seconds, yet not be able to catch five slow moving people? It's a jarringly porous script.

Still, if you can get past these things that weigh the screenplay down, there are some terrifically exciting scenes involving some seriously amped up dinosaurs. This is especially apparent in the river scene towards the end of the film. I'll be perfectly honest: it's one of the most convincing monster attacks I've ever seen in a film. And most of it is animatronics, done by the sorely missed Stan Winston. To be fair, when you only have a cast of five people for most of your movie, you can see why they'd be quick to draw out these chase scenes. Otherwise, Spiney would've been allowed to live up to a much fuller potential. And he is quite the ferocious antagonist when allowed to be.

I guess what it all comes down to is that the film simply had too much promise with what it was given to work with: small cast, the loss of the original writer (Micheal Crichton) and just how much it had to live up to. But take it for what it's worth. It's short, sweet and to the point. And it at the very least can passively entertain without overstaying it's welcome. It has that over the second film, which takes too much time on very blandly written characters. The film knows it's strong points and devotes far more time to them.

Where the second film had too much going for it, this third film in the "Jurassic Park" series has too little.  Quite simply, "Jurassic Park 3" is twenty minutes too short, and let slip a great opportunity to have a Godzilla-esque 'battle royale' between the monstrous Spinosaurus and the series' iconic Tyrannosaurus Rex.  

Having the great Sam Neill reprise his role as Dr. Alan Grant keeps this film from one-star territory (and, similarly, direct-to-video territory).  The lack of Spielberg's direction is apparent, and felt.
